response.answer_text: Most people use “random” and “completely random” interchangeably, and that’s the correct way to read it here. There is a very technical distinction between “random” and “completely random” in a specific context (cf. http://msp.org/pjm/1967/21-1/pjm-v21-n1-p06-p.pdf), but almost no one is aware of that.

Completely random, in this case, means impossible to predict. I am not sure about every lottery, but one popular method is to have a large number of balls, each identical except for a number, in a rotating container. Then balls are picked out. Could this system be rigged? Sure. You could weight the balls differently, for instance. But, if it done correctly, this is completely random.

This isn't really an answer, more like a clarification: while lottery numbers are practically random, in that you really can't predict them, they do of course follow the principle of cause and effect, as any macroscopic phenomenon will. If you knew all the variables, you could predict the outcome. But no one on earth knows all the variables, so no one could predict them. Of course I could come up with a very predictable lottery: it would use a deterministic pseudorandom algorithm to come up with the numbers. If you knew the algorithm and the seed, you'd know the numbers.

Completely random in this sense usually means that each number has the same probability of being selected each time the game is played, i.e., probability of selecting any one number is one over the total amount of numbers in the lottery.
